hanzi-su-wiki:
呉

Значения

Давать, дарить

Мнемоника

Искажено. Человек с запрокинутой головой 夭 и рот 口 в значении «зов, выкрик». Название провинции Го (по-китайски «У»), откуда в Японию попала письменность. Отсюда — «давать» (письменность). Входит в состав знака «ошибочный». Язык княжества Го — всего лишь китайский диалект.

Варианты

吳, 吴, 𠯵

Japanese variant of 吴
Японский вариант Ву
rtega_mnemonic:
吳吳RS
吴吴		呉one of warring states, give
  • RS. a man 大 with a jug 口 on his shoulder: probably the state of Wu, may have been originally noted for pottery; he gives something from his jug
heisig_constituent: give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs
heisig_story: The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar.
koohiiStory1: Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, "My uncle gave me this watch." Following -て form of another verb, means "to do the favor of": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, "Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?" Usu. written in hiragana.
koohiiStory2: I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!
jp_example_words: 呉れる(くれる): to give, to let one have, to do for one, to be given
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You've learned that you can catapult things to give them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: If you want to give someone something, use a catapult!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: You give Godzilla old used cars, chunks of old buildings, and sometimes hamburgers. Godzilla is so happy you're giving him food, he doesn't destroy anymore!
Ru_Meaning: give, do something for, kingdom of Wu
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the mouth (口) on a shelf (𠃊) on a table (丌) gives

Heisig: The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar.
koohii1: Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, "My uncle gave me this watch." Following -て form of another verb, means "to do the favor of": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, "Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?" Usu. written in hiragana.
koohii2: I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!

Radicals: 呉  (catapult)
Meaning Mnemonic
You've learned that you can catapult things to give them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.
If you want to give someone something, use a catapult!
Reading Mnemonic
Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.
You give Godzilla old used cars, chunks of old buildings, and sometimes hamburgers. Godzilla is so happy you're giving him food, he doesn't destroy anymore!
